Trend Of ROCEWhen we looked at the ROCE trend at Sysco, we didn't gain much confidence. Over the last five years, returns on capital have decreased to 10% from 21% five years ago. And considering revenue has dropped while employing more capital, we'd be cautious. If this were to continue, you might be looking at a company that is trying to reinvest for growth but is actually losing market share since sales haven't increased.

Our total Sysco results for the fourth quarter include a sales decrease of 43% to $8.9 billion. Local case volume within US Broadline operations decreased 38.7% for the fourth quarter, while total case volume within US Broadline operations decreased 41.5%. As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, we saw a significant decline in both volume and sales across all the business segments. Gross profit decreased 47% to $1.6 billion and gross margin decreased 159 basis points. Our gross margin for the fourth quarter was impacted by pricing to help move inventory and avoid spoilage and by a temporary shift in customer mix as a result of the current operating environment. These results were in line with our previous guidance as it relates to margins.Adjusted operating expense decreased 26% to $1.6 billion. It is important to note that we had $115 million of incentive pay accrual reversals that favorably impacted operating expenses and the run rate in Q1 of fiscal 2021 will be normalized when compared to Q4 fiscal 2020. With that said, the adjusted operating income run rate was profitable in June, even with -- even without the accrual reversal. Adjusted operating income decreased 104% to a loss of $34 million and adjusted earnings per share decreased 126% to a negative $0.29 for total Sysco. Across the business, our results were impacted by various financial certain items, which I will review before proceeding into individual segment results.

If anyone is looking for a Pure Earnings Short Sell play for Monday, I would highly suggest you check out SYY. I have spent 4 hours researching all stocks that report earnings Monday AH/Tuesday PM, about 200 stocks in total, and for me SYY stands out as being absolutely poised to sell-off immediately upon releasing earnings. I am enthusiastic about this play and think it offers about 80% odds of success, which is as good as you can get using this strategy. What makes SYY the most Bloated Baby of them all?? Consider:1: Stock is right at her 52 week high. In fact hit a brand new 52 week high on Friday. 2: Company was unable to generate a profit for 2020 despite being a wholesaler of vital goods.3: Valuation is astronomical with no justification.4: EPS is expected to be lower this quarter than last quarter, with negative growth. 5: A comprehensive financial analysis shows lots of weakness: Debt is high and significant. Gross Margins are below par for the sector. Return on Equity is weak. Growth rate is downright POOR for the sector. 6: Tons of uncertainty going forward due to high international exposure to restaurant and hotel business that can easily be devastated by the ongoing pandemic, as has occurred in India. 7: Despite being a wholesale food and food related supplier, SYY does NOT primarily serve supermarkets or pharmacies, which are booming. Rather, it primarily serves restaurants, hotels, schools, places that have seen and are likely to continue to see cuts in spending due to the pandemic. So, WHY is this stock so expensive??? Irrational Exuberance and the booming bull market lifts almost all stocks these days, making it a Pickers Paradise for the astute Short Seller. Even if SYY exactly meets EPS and Revenue consensus estimates on Tuesday, I judge Fair Value for this stock to be $67-$72/share. If they miss on both, $60-$65/share. If they modestly BEAT consensus on both, $74-$77/share. All this makes SYY a SCREAMING Short Sell to play and hold through her earnings release, and that is exactly what I plan to do on Monday, after I cover my current ON Pure Earnings Short Sell. Good Luck!

What an “Amazing“ opportunity to accumulate!SYSCO will continue to show consistent profit growth, even taking in to consideration the currently recovering market. It retains the highest margins comparable to its competitors, as well as market share. SYY monopolizes the food industry's North American distribution network, and continues to purse growth in to the international markets. Looking at the strength of its financials, I believe SYSCO has not only a proven track record, but the potential to well exceed its current depressed levels in the months to come.
